tossups.question: Note to moderators: you are doing a great job! Thanks for staffing! This character compares an “immense desert” to Victor Hugo’s idea of the “Living Infinite.” This character screams “I am the oppressed, and there is the oppressor!” after spotting a ship and mourning his dead family. A flag with this man’s motto “Mobilis in Mobili” is hoisted over the South Pole. This fervent anti-imperialist was born as Prince (*) Dakkar, the son of a Hindu raja. Five Civil War prisoners discover this character after their balloon crashes on the Mysterious Island. In an 1870 novel, this character rescues Professor Aronnax on the Abraham Lincoln using a vessel that is attacked by a giant squid and sent into a maelstrom. For 10 points, Jules Verne wrote about what captain of the Nautilus in Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea?
tossups.answer: Captain Nemo [accept Prince Dakkar until read]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~27467~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

tossups.question: Players of this instrument may practice exercises by Mauro Giuliani and Matteo Carcassi and use p-i-m-a notation. This instrument plays both arpeggios and a tremolo melody in a solo piece titled for “Memories of” a certain palace. The Nokia ringtone was excerpted from a piece for this instrument called Gran Vals written by Francisco Tárrega. This instrument is the soloist in (*) Joaquín Rodrigo’s Concierto de Aranjuez (“con-see-AIR-toh day ar-AHN-hwayz”), which was often performed by Andrés Segovia. Players of this instrument may learn how to read tab notation and chord charts. For 10 points, name this six-stringed instrument often strummed in flamenco music.
tossups.answer: guitar [accept specific examples such as classical guitar, acoustic guitar, or flamenco guitar] (The second line is Recuerdos de la Alhambra.)
tossups.metadata: Ivvone Zhou, Fine Arts - Music - Romantic> ~27799~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

tossups.question: During this conflict, the printing press of the Herald of Freedom was melted down for a “second edition” of cannonballs that destroyed Fort Titus. A speech made about this conflict compared a senator to Don Quixote. This conflict involved fighting at the Wakarusa River Valley. The New England Emigrant Aid Company provided (*) arms for one faction in this conflict. The Free State Hotel was targeted by a side in this conflict. Andrew Butler was targeted in a speech about the “Crime Against” the location of this conflict. During this conflict, the Lecompton Constitution drew the support of armed border ruffians. For 10 points, name this conflict between pro- and anti-slavery factions in a state with capital at Topeka.
tossups.answer: Bleeding Kansas [or Bloody Kansas; or the Border War in Kansas; accept “The Crime Against Kansas”; accept answers relating to the conflict caused by Kansas-Nebraska Act; prompt on answers like Kansas Civil War; reject “Civil War”]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - American - Pre-1865> ~27423~ <Editor: Arjun Nageswaran

tossups.question: Three values of this physical quantity are divided by the sines of angles in Lami’s (“lah-MEE’s”) theorem. This quantity appears in a cross product and is decomposed in Varignon’s (“var-ee-NYON’s”) theorem. Orthogonal displacement of two opposite-valued instances of this quantity yields a namesake “couple.” A linear combination of three forms of this quantity is dotted with virtual displacement in d’Alembert’s (“dah-lum-BEAR’s”) principle. Orthogonal components of this quantity are summed in its (*) “Lorentz” form in electromagnetic fields. Equilibrium is reestablished by a “restoring” form of this quantity. This quantity’s moment is torque, which equals its product with the lever arm. For 10 points, name this quantity represented by arrows in free body diagrams.
tossups.answer: force [accept net force or force couple or Lorentz force or restoring force]
tossups.metadata: David Bass, Science - Physics> ~28621~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: In a painting inspired by a magazine, an artist performs this action as his lover Peter Schlesinger, wearing a pink suit jacket, looks down. In an 1885 painting, an artist controversially depicted himself in the bottom right corner performing this action alongside his students. A person performing this action is represented by a white blotch of paint behind a protruding yellow (*) rectangle, in front of palm trees and an empty director’s chair, in a painting by David Hockney. A boy stands on a stone wall and watches as young men perform this action in a Thomas Eakins painting. For 10 points, a Georges Seurat painting depicts boys performing what action along the Seine “at Asnières (“ahn-yair”)?”
tossups.answer: swimming [or word forms such as having a swim; accept The Swimming Hole; accept synonyms such as bathing; accept Bathers at Asnières or Une Baignade, Asnières; accept having a dip; accept floating or wading; accept diving or jumping into a pool or jumping into water; prompt on jumping; prompt on splashing; prompt on being naked or nude] (The first painting is Hockney’s Portrait of an Artist (Pool with Two Figures). Hockney’s other painting clued is A Bigger Splash.)

tossups.question: This commander broke the last of 31 kings by destroying a northern alliance at the Waters of Merom. The Hivites of Gibeon (“hih-VYTES of GIB-ee-uhn”) used worn sandals to trick this commander out of fear over his tendency to put every living thing to the sword upon conquering them. A planned retreat by this commander lured Bethelite forces from their defensive positions, allowing his reserves to burn (*) Ai (“AY-ee”). The documentary Battles BC postulated that this commander used a red cord hanging from a brothel’s window to infiltrate a besieged city while his men marched around it for seven days; shofar blows then signaled those infiltrators to bring down Jericho’s walls. For 10 points, the Israelite invasion of Canaan was led by what successor of Moses?
tossups.answer: Joshua
tossups.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - Hebrew Bible> ~28628~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: Medieval residents of this city climbed greased Cuccagna (“coo-KAHN-yah”) trees to reach a stuffed bird during its Feast of the Roast Pig. A statue of Neptune in this city’s Piazza Maggiore (“mah-JOR-ay”) inspired the logo of one of its major car companies. Mundinus inaugurated this city’s tradition of public dissections, which were often accompanied by music. This city is home to the headquarters of Maserati and Lamborghini. Flat tagliatelle (“tah-lee-ah-TELL-ay”) pasta often accompanies this city’s namesake (*) meat-based sauce. Umberto Eco established the “Anthropology of the West” in this European city at the oldest continuously-operating university in the world. The capital of Emilia-Romagna is, for 10 points, what Italian city that names a type of ground pork sausage?
tossups.answer: Bologna [accept the University of Bologna; accept Sant’Agata Bolognese; accept beef bolognese or Bolognese sauce; prompt on Sant’Agata; prompt on baloney with “what city is that named for?”] (Baloney was the American pronunciation of the city for several decades.)
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Geography - Europe> ~27411~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: C. Wright Mills coined the term for a “crackpot” version of this word in The Causes of World War Three. This word follows “capitalist” in the name of an art movement co-founded by Pop-inflected German artists such as Gerhard Richter. It’s not liberalism, but Kenneth Waltz’s Theory of International Politics outlined a school of international relations that re-emphasized the importance of power politics and whose name attaches (*) “neo” to this word. Paintings such as Chuck Close’s Big Self-Portrait are part of a genre named for “photo” and this word, also a term used for cutting-edge video game graphics. For 10 points, name this word that generally describes art that aims for a truthful depiction.
tossups.answer: realism [accept word forms like realist or real or realistic; accept photorealism or neorealism or capitalist realism or crackpot realism or other word forms]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~27724~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: A character in this novel uses golden strings to feel the pulse of a ruler and prescribes a medicine of “black gold” for his anxiety. A character in this novel kidnaps the daughter of a village elder and exposes his identity through his insatiable appetite; that character carries a rake and is tasked with cleaning altars in this novel. A weapon from this novel was originally an iron (*) pillar owned by the Dragon King that could change size. After eating the peaches of immortality, a character in this novel is tricked by the Buddha’s palm and becomes trapped under a mountain. For 10 points, name this novel that follows the title pilgrimage of the monk Táng Sānzàng and Monkey King Sūn Wùkōng.
tossups.answer: Journey to the West [accept Xīyóujì; prompt on Monkey with “what is the title of the non-abridged version of that work”]
tossups.metadata: Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~28073~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: After this event, one leader stayed at Ian Fleming’s estate for a month amid concerns of his benzedrine addiction. Joel Beinin traced a mass expulsion that occurred during this event to distrust from the Lavon Affair two years prior. The Sixth Fleet blocked the IMF from sending aid during this event despite one leader’s insistence that the Americans would “lie doggo.” One side during this event launched Operation (*) Musketeer to open up the Straits of Tiran. Lester Pearson won a Nobel Peace Prize for mediating this event’s end, after which Anthony Eden resigned. For 10 points, name this 1956 conflict in which France, Britain, and Israel jointly invaded Egypt over a structure nationalized by Gamal Abdel Nasser.
tossups.answer: Suez Crisis [or the Suez Canal Crisis; accept Tripartite Aggression] (The second clue refers to Nasser’s expulsion of Egyptian Jews.)
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - World - African> ~27304~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: When this concept is first introduced, a character notices the “absolute simplicity” of it and lets out a “respectful whistle.” A chapter named after this concept ends with the protagonist being stabbed by a woman holding a bone-handled kitchen knife before being saved by two colonels. This concept is introduced as a law that is illegal to read. An example of this concept results in a profit being made off of (*) eggs that are bought for seven cents each and sold for five cents each. Doc Daneeka refuses to discharge any pilots for insanity because of this concept, which states that any pilot who asks to be grounded isn’t crazy. For 10 points, name this paradoxical loophole that titles a Joseph Heller novel.
tossups.answer: Catch-22 [or the Catch-22 paradox]
tossups.metadata: Anthony Troullier, Literature - American - Long Fiction> ~28192~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: A controversy named for these objects was resolved when Deputy Secretary Roswell Gilpatric found only 10 examples of R-7s in Corona photos. In 1984, a young Ash Carter told Congress that a proposed system of X-rays would be ineffective against these objects. A technology to counter these items, the Nike Zeus, was canceled by Robert McNamara. Canada installed (*) Bomarc examples of these items instead of sticking with the Avro Arrow. They’re not bombers, but the Kennedy campaign exploited the false notion that the US had a “gap” in these weapons. These weapons would have been destroyed by the Reagan-era SDI program, which critics dubbed “Star Wars.” For 10 points, name these weapons fired from silos.
tossups.answer: missiles [or ICBMs; or intercontinental ballistic missiles; or nuclear missiles; accept anti-ballistic missile or ABM; accept missile gap; prompt on warheads or rockets or bombs or nuclear bombs or nukes]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~27099~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: This character laments how her own body “seemed nothing—nothing at all” while admiring the “slow and stately” figure of Lady Bexborough. This character thinks fondly of the clever sayings of a former love interest, such as a quip about preferring “men to cauliflowers.” This character reminisces about the “most exquisite moment” of her life, which is when her friend picked a flower from a stone urn and (*) kissed her on the lips. Despite choosing Richard over Peter Walsh, this character wishes she could have had the choice to marry her childhood friend Sally Seton. For 10 points, a 1925 stream-of-consciousness novel by Virginia Woolf follows a day in the life of what title woman?
tossups.answer: Clarissa Dalloway [accept Mrs. Dalloway]
tossups.metadata: Wonyoung Jang, Literature - British - Long Fiction

tossups.question: Ions like benzyl·pyridinium are named for these devices because they always fragment the same way in ESI mass spec. These devices’ two-point calibration scale was invented by astronomer Ole Rømer (“OHL-uh RUM-er”). A type of these devices measures the e·m·f from two alloys spliced at a Seebeck junction. Essentially, the Zeroth Law allows these devices to exist. In psych·rometry, these devices are wrapped in a damp cloth to provide (*) “wet bulb” measurements. These devices are poked through a Styrofoam lid and provide experimental data from a coffee cup calorimeter. For safety, red-dyed ethanol is used today in these devices instead of liquid mercury. For 10 points, Daniel Fahrenheit invented what type of device that measures temperature?
tossups.answer: thermometers [or thermosensors; accept thermocouples; accept mercury thermometer or alcohol thermometer; accept temperature sensors until the end of the tossup, and prompt afterwards]
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~27535~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: One historian claimed that people from this region descended from the underworld god Dis (“dees”) and thus emphasized night more than day. Aurelian claimed the title Restitutor Orbis after defeating a splinter state in this region led by Postumus. A king from this region threw his sword on scales and declared “vae victis” (“WHY WICK-tees”) after winning the Battle of the (*) Allia. Aulus Hirtius partially authored a series of works that describes campaigns against this region’s Helvetii tribe. Brennus was from this region, where one commander used contravallation to defeat Vercingetorix (“ver-sin-GEH-tuh-ricks”) at the Siege of Alesia. For 10 points, Julius Caesar wrote a set of commentaries on his campaigns in what Roman province, which encompasses much of modern France?
tossups.answer: Gaul [accept Gallia; accept Gallic Empire or Gallic Roman Empire; accept Cisalpine Gaul; prompt on France]
tossups.metadata: Abhinav Rachakonda, History - European - Classical> ~27865~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: The earliest writings in this philosophical tradition were satirical poems called silloi written by Timon of Phlius. Diogenes Laërtius claimed that this tradition’s founder accompanied Anaxarchus to India and was influenced by the gymnosophists. A book on the “Outlines” of one form of this tradition distinguishes it from Carneades’s “Academic” form. Edmund Husserl was influenced by this tradition’s practice of (*) epoché (“eh-po-KAY”), or bracketing. Sextus Empiricus was a philosopher from this tradition that, like Stoicism and Epicureanism, believed that the highest good was a state of suspended judgment called ataraxia. For 10 points, Pyrrho of Elis founded what philosophical tradition that doubts the possibility of certain knowledge?
tossups.answer: skepticism [or skeptics; accept Academic skepticism; accept Pyrrhonism until “Pyrrho”; accept Outlines of Pyrrhonism until “Pyrrho”]
tossups.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Philosophy> ~28126~ <Editor: Vincent Du

tossups.question: This element is dominant in the emission spectra of many subtypes of both WN and WC types of Wolf–Rayet stars. This element is the most abundant reactant in a reaction with rate proportional to the forty-first power of temperature that yields the Hoyle state. This element’s stellar mass fraction is denoted “capital Y.” Stars enter the horizontal branch after this element’s runaway (*) “flash.” This is the heaviest non-negligible element present in population III (“three”) stars because they formed from primordial gas. This element was discovered by observing the Sun’s chromosphere during a solar eclipse. Three atoms of this element fuse into carbon-12 in the triple-alpha process. For 10 points, name this second-lightest element.
tossups.answer: helium [or He; accept helium flash] (The equation “X + Y + Z = 1” describes stellar composition in terms of the mass fractions of hydrogen, helium, and all other elements, respectively.)
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Science - Astronomy> ~17105~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: A makeup artist from this country created glass-like skin to make models resemble porcelain dolls for a 2024 Maison Margiela runway show. This country is home to a designer whose “contemporary minimalism” revived Celine in 2008 and who launched the eponymous brand Phoebe Philo in 2023. An actress born in this country names a purse that was conceived during a conversation on a plane between her and the chairman of the French company (*) Hermès (“air-mezz”). Interest in this country’s Teddy Boy subculture was renewed by Vivienne Westwood. A woman from this country wore a "revenge dress" when her husband confessed to cheating on her with Camila Strand. For 10 points, name this country where an Alexander McQueen gown was worn during a royal wedding by Kate Middleton.
tossups.answer: United Kingdom [or the UK; or Great Britain; prompt on England]
tossups.metadata: Bryanna Shao, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~28167~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: A god refuses entry to one of these figures at Mount Kailash, causing that figure to impatiently strike out with a weapon gifted to him by Shiva (“SHI-vuh”). Five lakes swell with the blood of the twenty-one warrior generations slain by one of these figures, who, in another myth, uses his axe to chop off Ganesha’s tusk. During the rasalila (“ra-sa-LEE-la”), one of these figures duplicates himself to dance with the (*) gopis (“GO-peas”) and Radha. Holi celebrates how a half-lion one of these figures burst from a pillar to save Prahlada (“pruh-huh-LAH-duh”). Arjuna learns about dharma from one of these figures who acts as his charioteer in the Bhagavad Gita. For 10 points, Parashurama (“puh-ruh-shoe-RAH-muh”) and Narasimha (“nuh-ruh-SIM-huh”) number among what ten incarnations of the Preserver, such as Krishna?
tossups.answer: avatars of Vishnu [or Dashavatara; prompt on partial answer; accept incarnations of Vishnu until said; accept reasonable equivalents like forms of Vishnu; prompt on Hindu gods or deities or Indian gods or deities or Vedic gods or deities]
tossups.metadata: Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - World Mythology> ~27964~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: Two enzymes in this organelle use lipoic (“lie-POH-ick”) acid as an anti·oxidant. A heme (“heem”), iron-sulfur, and flavoprotein complex in this organelle de·hydrogenates a four-carbon di·carboxylic acid, then uses the hydrogen to convert coenzyme Q to QH2. To maintain this organelle’s redox potential, cells shuttle electrons into it via malate, rather than pumping in reduced (*) nico·tin·amide. Complexes I (“one”) through IV (“four”) dock in this organelle. This organelle oxidizes acetyl-CoA by condensing it with oxalo·acetate, then uses energy stored in NADH to build up a chemiosmotic (“kem-ee-oz-MAH-tick”) proton gradient. The cristae (“KRIS-tay”) folds of this organelle contain ATP synthase. For 10 points, name this organelle that houses the Krebs cycle and electron transport chain.
tossups.answer: mitochondria [or mitochondrion]
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Biology> ~27621~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: This substance inspired an essay where the author describes three “Ladies of Sorrow” that accompany the Roman goddess of childbirth. In a book titled for this substance, the author describes re-reading a book by David Ricardo for two years and taking walks down Oxford Street with the teenage prostitute Ann. In The Picture of Dorian Gray, Dorian is first confronted by Sibyl Vane’s brother at a place associated with this substance. This substance influenced the prose of the collection (*) Suspiria De Profundis. The “Pleasures” and “Pains” of this substance are described in a set of “Confessions” of a user of this substance. For 10 points, Thomas de Quincey wrote of abusing what drug derived from poppies?
tossups.answer: opium [or laudanum; accept Confessions of an English Opium-Eater; prompt on psychoactive drugs]
tossups.metadata: Ethan Ashbrook, Literature - British - Other> ~27777~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: This word alternatively names the izze-kloth, an Apache “cord” that confers strength and that cannot be touched or discussed by nonbelievers. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this word which also names a four-colored indigenous “wheel” appropriated by the plastic shaman Charles Storm. This word alternatively names shaman-like healers in Indigenous American communities.
Sweetgrass, sage, and cedar are among the four sacred medicines used during this purifying ritual where participants immerse themselves in smoke to banish negative forces.
Smudging is used to purify lodges named for this bodily process, which is induced through steam generated from water poured onto hot rocks.
answers: medicine [accept medicine wheel; accept four sacred medicines; accept medicine men or women]
smudging [accept burning a smudge stick; prompt on burning herbs]
sweat [accept word forms such as sweating; accept perspiration; accept sweat lodges or sweathouses]
bonuses.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - Other Religion> ~23649~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: This effect shifts a site frequency spectrum to the right by making rare mutations more common. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this effect, a form of genetic drift in which a non-representative sample of individuals is geographically isolated from a group.
Founder effects suppress the “effective” form of this quantity, which is a metric of genetic diversity. Carrying capacity is a limit on this value.

The effective population size is the fraction of a population with this property over four times the mutation rate. In a population with complementary gene frequencies p, q, and r, the expected frequency of this property is [read slowly] “1 minus p squared minus q squared minus r squared.”
answers: population size [prompt on size; prompt on N; prompt on number of individuals]

bonuses.leadin: “Weasels that stole” these animals are among the things Emily Dickinson Wellcome “defended herself” against, according to the poem “Dedication for a Plot of Ground.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name these animals. An Imagist poem describes an object “glazed with rain / water / beside” these animals.
This author wrote that poem, “The Red Wheelbarrow,” as well as “This Is Just To Say.”

In the author’s note to his epic poem Paterson, Williams stated that “for the poet” there is this five-word refrain. This refrain repeats throughout the poem and is twice preceded by the phrase “say it!”
bonuses.metadata: Joseph Krol, Literature - American - Poetry> ~23306~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: Lauren Berlant and Sara Ahmed have applied the study of this concept to feminist and queer theory. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these states, closely related to emotions but also involving bodily responses and the capacity to act, that were the subject of a late-90s flowering of scholarship in literary theory and the social sciences.

Affect theorists draw on this book’s classification of the affects, which it defines as “modifications to the body” that increase or decrease its active power. This 1677 book uses the method of Euclid to identify God with nature.
Ethics is the magnum opus of this Dutch Jewish thinker of the early modern period.
bonuses.metadata: Vincent Du, RMP - Philosophy> ~23283~ <Editor: Vincent Du

bonuses.leadin: This country’s “razor gangs” were led by crime bosses such as Tilly Devine, the “Queen of Woolloomooloo.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this modern-day country where an 1850s gold rush brought huge numbers to Ballarat and other sites in its state of Victoria.
This Australian bushranger, who committed several murders at Stringybark Creek, made a homemade suit of bulletproof armor for his final shootout with the police at Glenrowan.

Australian outlaw Kate Leigh controlled shops that sold illicit alcohol called “sly [this term].” This term names a drink that was part of Royal Navy rations from 1756 to 1970 using a recipe devised by Vice-Admiral Edward Vernon.
bonuses.metadata: Jaimie Carlson, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~23299~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: Other than “the massive fire,” the main reason you shouldn’t run a battery on the thermite reaction is that it only provides 1.6 of these units. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this SI unit for the electric potential difference across a battery.
The voltage is low because fully reducing ferric iron in this oxidation state is unfavorable. Aluminum acquires this charge in the thermite reaction.

You’d get twice the voltage from a thermite battery between aluminum and the plus-three ion of this element, which has the highest electron affinity and electronegativity of any metal. This transition metal’s only other common oxidation state is plus-one.
answers: +3 [or plus-three or positive three; prompt on three by itself]
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~22804~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: The speaker of this poem decries the “savage race” that “hoard, and sleep, and feed, and not know me.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poem whose speaker laments “How dull it is to pause / to make an end.” This poem’s second stanza focuses on the speaker’s love for his “most blameless” son to whom he leaves “the sceptre and the isle.”
“Ulysses” is a poem by this English poet who also wrote “Crossing the Bar” and “The Charge of the Light Brigade.”
Odysseus’s possible disappointment with his return to his homeland is also chronicled in this author’s 1911 poem “Ithaka.” This author also wrote “Waiting for the Barbarians.”
answers: Constantine Cavafy [or C. P. Cavafy or Co Constantine P. Cavafy; or Konstantinos Petrou Kavafis]
bonuses.metadata: Zac Bennett, Literature - British - Poetry> ~22917~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: A chaperon (“sha-pear-OHN”) fashioned like one of these objects sometimes titles a painting whose date of “October 21, 1433” is painted to resemble an etching on its frame. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this object of clothing, a red one of which is worn by a man in a black fur coat in a possible self-portrait by Jan van Eyck.
This man wears a red, twisted bourrelet (“BOOR-ley”) in a 1438 van Eyck portrait. This man holds the hand of a pregnant woman in a green dress in a van Eyck painting believed to depict a wedding.
English or original language term required. This phrase appears at the top of the frame for Man in the Red Turban. This pun was Van Eyck’s motto and was written in pseudo-Greek letters.
answers: turban [or a red turban; accept Portrait of a Man in a Turban; accept Portrait of a Man in a Red Turban; prompt on hats or headware or scarves]
Giovanni Arnolfini [or Giovanni di Nicolao Arnolfini; accept the Arnolfini Portrait; or Arnolfini Wedding; or Arnolfini Marriage; or the Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife]

“As I Can” [or “Als Ich Can”; accept “As Eyck Can”; accept “As Best I Can” or “As Best Eyck Can”; accept “As Well as I Can” or “As Well as Eyck Can”; accept “As Best I Can, Not as I Would” or “As Best I can, Not as Eyck Would”]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - European to 1600> ~22733~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: At the breakup of Austria-Hungary, about three-quarters of its industrial capacity was in what became this country. For 10 points each:
parts: Škoda Auto was founded in what country, which industrialized under Tomáš (“toh-mahsh”) Masaryk and Edvard Beneš (“beh-nesh”)?
Before making cars, Škoda operated in this industry, including making products with the Czech-derived name “howitzer.”

Škoda’s local competitors included Tatra, whose model named for this number was the first mass-produced aerodynamically-shaped car. Vaclav Havel and other dissidents signed a charter named for this number calling on the Czechoslovak government to respect human rights.
answers: arms industry [or defense industry; accept making weapons or guns or military equipment; accept artillery or cannons]

bonuses.leadin: This pianist wrote his third and favorite piano concerto for his 1909 tour of the US. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Russian composer of four virtuosic piano concertos and Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini.

This American pianist won the first Tchaikovsky Competition in 1958 by playing Tchaikovsky and Rach (“rock”) 3. Yunchan Lim went viral for his performance of Rach 3 in the final round of a 2022 competition named for this pianist held every four years in Fort Worth, Texas.

For the Cliburn Competition, Lim also played all 12 of these pieces in one sitting. This solo piano collection by Franz Liszt includes “Feux follets” (“FUH foh-LAY”), “Mazeppa,” and “Chasse-neige” (“SHAHSS-nehj”).
answers: Van Cliburn [or Harvey Lavan Cliburn Jr.; accept Van Cliburn International Piano Competition]
bonuses.metadata: Ivvone Zhou, Fine Arts - Music - Romantic> ~22734~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

bonuses.leadin: In the first line of a novel, this author evocatively describes the smell of cyanide and associates it with “the fate of unrequited love.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Colombian author of Love in the Time of Cholera and One Hundred Years of Solitude.
One Hundred Years of Solitude opens with Aureliano Buendía facing the firing squad and remembering the day his father took him to discover this substance.
In the first line of a different García Márquez novella, this character gets up at five-thirty to wait for the bishop, despite getting back late from a wedding the day before.
answers: Santiago Nasar [or Santiago Nasar] (From Chronicle of a Death Foretold.)
bonuses.metadata: Joseph Krol, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~23315~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: Instead of facing these questions, sons of Laius (“LIE-us”) who sought their sister’s throne were asked to recite the prophecy Cadmus was given at Delphi. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these questions that were asked on Mount Phicium. One of these questions greeted travelers by asking for the creature with one voice, while another refers to Day and Night as sisters who birthed each other.
Answer the Sphinx’s modernized riddle: What walks on four legs in the morning, two legs at noon, and three legs in the evening?
The Sphinx killed Haemon, the son of this Theban king, whose sister Jocasta married Oedipus.
answers: riddles of the Sphinx [accept word forms such as the Sphinx’s riddles; prompt on riddles by asking “who posited them?”]
man [accept woman, people, and humans; accept equivalents] (The actual riddle is more like “What is it that has one voice, and is four-footed, two-footed, and three-footed?”)
bonuses.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~22586~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: Allen G. Thurman, a  74-year-old running mate of this man, gave a bizarre speech stating, “I am not quite as well as I ought to be.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Democrat who lost the 1888 election with Thurman but won four years later against the same opponent with the elder Adlai Stevenson as his running mate.
This candidate’s running mate, James Stockdale, asked on the debate stage, “Who am I? Why am I here?” This third-party candidate topped some polls in 1992 against Bill Clinton and George H. W. Bush.
Although this man was deemed too old to become FDR’s running mate in 1944, he ran on the 1948 ticket with Truman. This man may have been the first VP to be nicknamed “veep.”

bonuses.leadin: Border disputes have made a comeback in the 2020s. For 10 points each:
parts: Two answers required. A dispute about the reach of the Exclusive Economic Zone of one of these two countries has led the other to threaten to seize the island of Kastellorizo. These two countries once engaged in “earthquake diplomacy.”
In 2023, this president of Venezuela ordered new maps printed in all the country’s schools showing Venezuela now possessed long-disputed territory with Guyana.
This proposed border in the South China Sea gets its name from a map amended by Mao Zedong in 1952. A supposed depiction of this border caused the government of Vietnam to ban the Barbie film.
answers: Greece AND Turkey [accept Hellenic Republic for Greece; accept the Republic of Türkiye for Turkey]
nine-dash line [or nine-segment line; or nánhǎi duànxùxiàn; or jiǔduàn xiàn; prompt on South Sea intermittent line; reject “eleven-dash line” or “ten-dash line”; reject “shíyīduàn xiàn”]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~23204~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: The quantum form of this interaction motivates M-theory and names a theory that implements it with namesake “loops.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this interaction that gives rise to the hierarchy problem because it is 24 orders of magnitude weaker than another one.

Loop quantum gravity seeks to reformulate GR as a background-less one of these theories. Yang–Mills theory exemplifies these field theories in which the Lagrangian is invariant under namesake local transformations in a Lie (“LEE”) group.
LQG is contrasted with theories of these hypothetical one-dimensional objects that compose all matter. Theories of these objects feature many extra dimensions.
answers: gravity [or gravitation or gravitational force or gravitational interaction; accept quantum gravity or quantum gravitation or quantum gravitational force]
bonuses.metadata: Lalit Maharjan, Science - Physics> ~23762~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: A poem that begins “after every war / someone has to clean up” ends by describing someone with this substance “in his mouth / gazing at the clouds.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this substance, which “has overgrown causes and effects” in “The End and the Beginning.” A child asks “What is [this substance]?” in a collection named for this “uncut hair of graves.”
“The End and the Beginning” was written by this poet of “Salt” and Calling Out to Yeti. This Polish Nobel laureate lists reasons that a woman could have looked back in “Lot’s Wife.”
Szymborska is from this country, whose national epic is Adam Mickiewicz’s (“meets-KYAY-veech”) Pan Tadeusz (“pahn tah-DAY-oosh”). Joseph Conrad moved from this modern-day nation to the UK.
answers: grass [or “blades of grass”; or trawie or kłosem; accept “an ear of corn” as that is an alternate translation for kłosem; accept Leaves of Grass]
bonuses.metadata: Jaimie Carlson, Literature - European - Poetry> ~23294~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

bonuses.leadin: A “Federation” named for this two-word term collapsed in 1962 following Eric Williams’s observation that “one from ten leaves nought.” For 10 points each:
parts: Christopher Columbus’s expeditions originated what two-word term for the Antilles and the Lucayan Archipelago?
Williams’s comment referred to this island’s decision to leave the West Indies Federation. Queen Nanny organized maroons to resist European colonization of this island.
Jamaica left the Federation under a premier with this last name. A 1970s prime minister of Jamaica with this last name held hands with his rival Edward Seaga at Bob Marley’s One Love Concert.
answers: West Indies [accept West Indies Federation or Federation of the West Indies or West Indian Federation]
bonuses.metadata: Joseph Krol, History - World - Latin American> ~23463~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

bonuses.leadin: A bandleader with this first name and the surname Tipton was discovered to possibly be transgender after his death. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this first name of the composer of “Lush Life,” who wrote about “the quickest way to Harlem” in a song for a different bandleader.

Billy Strayhorn was a gay member of this pianist’s namesake Orchestra, which performed “Take the A-Train” at the Cotton Club. This pianist’s standards include “In a Sentimental Mood” and “It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing).”
Tipton’s story is similar to “Little Ax” Broadnax, a quartet singer in this genre. Mahalia Jackson and James Cleveland recorded this religious music genre.
answers: Billy [accept Bill or Will or William; accept Billy Tipton or Billy Strayhorn]
gospel music [or traditional gospel music or Black gospel or urban contemporary gospel or gospel quartet; prompt on Christian music]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Jazz> ~22895~ <Editor: Victor Pavao

bonuses.leadin: Gray code is a variant to this numeral system that is achieved by flipping each digit to the right of a one. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this numeral system that features only the digits zero and one.

Gray code guarantees that consecutive integers have distance one under this metric, which is bounded below by edit distance. For two binary strings, this metric equals the number of bit substitutions by which they differ.

The earliest “code” named for this task is Hamming-seven-comma-four, whose three parity bits can detect any variation of Hamming distance one. After detecting that the checksums of copies of a file differ, this task makes them equal.
answers: error correction [accept word forms like correcting errors; accept error-correcting codes]
bonuses.metadata: David Bass, Science - Computer Science> ~22722~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: The Matthew effect was coined to describe the accumulation of advantage by members of this profession. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this profession whose sociological study was popularized by Robert K. Merton. Thomas Kuhn argued that this profession engages in “puzzle-solving” between “paradigm shifts.”
The Merton thesis draws a link between Puritanism and the rise of experimental science, akin to this German sociologist’s claim that the Protestant work ethic led to capitalism.
Robert Merton’s sociology of science was influenced by Karl Mannheim’s “sociology of” this concept. Michael Polanyi coined a socially-transmitted “tacit” form of this concept.
answers: scientists [or word forms; accept scientific researchers; accept types of scientists like biologists and physicists]
bonuses.metadata: Vincent Du, Social Science - Sociology> ~23330~ <Editor: Vincent Du

bonuses.leadin: This country’s rapid growth in the late 20th century is a backdrop for Bessie Head’s novels. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country which became a British protectorate in 1885. This country’s first president, Seretse Khama, championed tribal ownership of natural resources.
Much of Botswana’s growth comes from diamond mines like Orapa co-run with this company. This company built the “Big Hole” at Kimberly.
Botswana was controlled by a political alliance known as the A-Team during this decade, during which apartheid ended and Nelson Mandela was elected president of South Africa.
answers: Botswana [or the Republic of Botswana or Lefatshe la Botswana; accept the Land of the Tswana; prompt on Bechuanaland]
De Beers [or the De Beers Group; accept De Beers Diamond Consortium]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, History - World - African> ~23205~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran
